lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/Tigger.Tigger.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Tigger.Tigger.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.

// Describe the action and its outcome.
// A description of the expected outcome goes here
* @param description Description of the deadline task.
* @param by          Deadline date as a string.
* @param from start date of the event
* @param to end date of the event
public Event(String description, String from, String to) {
* Parser class to handle user commands and manipulate the task list.
* @param command The user command to execute.
* @param list    The list of tasks to manipulate.
* @throws TiggerException If the command is invalid or cannot be processed.
public static void execute(String command, ArrayList<Task> list) throws TiggerException {
System.out.println("    Here are the tasks in your list:");
System.out.println("    Nice! I've marked this task as done: ");
System.out.println("    OK, I've marked this task as not done yet: ");
throw new TiggerException("What do you want me todo??");
System.out.println("    Got it. I've added this task:");
System.out.println("    Now you have " + list.size() + " tasks in the list");
throw new TiggerException("What's the deadline for??");
System.out.println("    Got it. I've added this task:");
System.out.println("    Now you have " + list.size() + " tasks in the list");
throw new TiggerException("Whats the new event??");
System.out.println("    Got it. I've added this task:");
Event d = new Event(splitCommand[0], splitCommand[1].trim(), splitCommand[2]);
System.out.println("    Now you have " + list.size() + " tasks in the list");
throw new TiggerException("What do you want me to delete??");
System.out.println("    Noted. I've removed this task:");
System.out.println("    Now you have " + list.size() + " tasks in the list");
throw new TiggerException("What do you want me to find??");
System.out.println("    Here are the matching tasks in your list:");
System.out.println("    No matching tasks found in your list.");
throw new TiggerException("Give me something I can understand!!");
* Class to handle storage of tasks to a file.
Event event = new Event(subCommand[2].trim(), subCommand[3].trim(), subCommand[4].trim());
* Saves the tasks to the storage file.
* @param tasks list of tasks to be saved
* Abstract class that represents a general task
return (isDone ? "X" : " "); // mark done task with X
* Public class for loading and saving tasks to tigger.txt.
* Chatbot named Tigger.Tigger that acts as a checklist.
System.out.println("    Bye. Hope to see you again soon!");
* Main method to start Tigger.Tigger chatbot.
* Custom exception class for Tigger chatbot.
* @param description description of the to-do task
* Handles user interaction for Tigger chatbot.
System.out.println("    What can I do for you?");
* Reads the next command from the user.
* @return true if the command is "bye", false otherwise
ToDo t = new ToDo("  my task  ");
assertFalse(t.isDone, "New ToDo should be not done by default");
assertEquals("my task", t.getDescription(), "Description should be trimmed");
assertTrue(t.isDone, "ToDo should be marked done after setDone");
assertTrue(t.isDone, "setDone should remain true when called again");
